stories.title: Andrej Karpathy: Software in the era of AI [video]
stories.author: sandslash
stories.article_summary: Article content too short to summarize effectively.

main_themes: Limited discussion with detailed analysis available
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The comments reflect a mix of skepticism and appreciation for the evolving conversation around programming paradigms and AI integration in software engineering. Commenters express concerns about the clarity and practicality of terms like 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0, likening them to marketing jargon. There is a recognition of the need for determinism and validation in programming, and a suggestion that the discussion is being elevated by figures like Andrej Karpathy. The overall sentiment indicates a desire for more concrete insights and practical applications in the AI and software engineering landscape.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter criticizes the progression of versions 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0 as marketing jargon that misrepresents programming concepts, suggesting that the discussion lacks substance and relies on selective analogies. They highlight a reinvention of the need for determinism and validation midway through, indicating a disconnect in the narrative.

top_comments.author: politelemon
top_comments.text:
The beginning was painful to watch as is the cheering in this comment section.
The 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0 simply aren't making sense. They imply a kind of a succession and replacement and demonstrate a lack of how programming works. It sounds as marketing oriented as "Web 3.0" that has been born inside an echo chamber. And yet halfway through, the need for determinism/validation is now being reinvented.
The analogies make use of cherry picked properties, which could apply to anything.

top_comments.author: monsieurbanana
top_comments.text:
> "Because they all have slight pros and cons, and you may want to program some functionality in 1.0 or 2.0, or 3.0, or you're going to train in LLM, or you're going to just run from LLM"
He doesn't say they will fully replace each other (or had fully replaced each other, since his definition of 2.0 is quite old by now)

top_comments.author: whiplash451
top_comments.text:
I think Andrej is trying to elevate the conversation in an interesting way.
That in and on itself makes it worth it.
No one has a crystal clear view of what is happening, but at least he is bringing a novel and interesting perspective to the field.

top_comments.author: amai
top_comments.text:
The quite good blog post mentioned by Karpathy for working with LLMs when building software:
- https://blog.nilenso.com/blog/2025/05/29/ai-assisted-coding/
See also:
- https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=44242051

top_comments.author: ramraj07
top_comments.text:
That is the greatest, most relatable post I have ever seen on AI in software engineering.
My brutal take at this point is that if you're not significantly more productive by an order of magnitude in your software work through the use of AI, it just means that you're just not that good, never were, and/or you work with the worst Designed systems out there. Your poor opinion of AI is literally a bad misinterpretation of the pathetic state of your own software development system (including you).

stories.title: TI to invest $60B to manufacture foundational semiconductors in the U.S.
stories.author: TMWNN
stories.article_summary: Texas Instruments (TI) has announced a historic investment of over $60 billion to expand semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S., marking the largest such investment in the nation's history. This initiative includes the construction of seven semiconductor fabs across mega-sites in Texas and Utah, which will create over 60,000 jobs. TI's Sherman site alone will see up to $40 billion allocated for four fabs (SM1, SM2, SM3, and SM4), with SM1 and SM2 already in progress. CEO Haviv Ilan stated, “TI is building dependable, low-cost 300mm capacity at scale,” emphasizing the critical role these chips play in various sectors, from automotive to healthcare. Partnerships with leading companies such as Apple, Ford, Medtronic, NVIDIA, and SpaceX highlight TI's commitment to driving innovation in American manufacturing and technology.

main_themes: Limited discussion with detailed analysis available
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The comments reflect skepticism towards Texas Instruments' ability to invest significantly given their current market cap and debt burden. There is a general sentiment of distrust regarding corporate promises and political advertisements, with a notable mention of the public's opposition to war despite political decisions.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter questions how Texas Instruments can afford a significant investment that represents about a third of its market cap, suggesting that such announcements may be more about maintaining appearances than actual follow-through.

top_comments.author: jppope
top_comments.text:
Someone correct me here, but Texas Instruments was one of the companies that mortgaged their future in the name of financialization (https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/yeah-its-still-water-ben-hunt...) and their market cap right now is ~170B...
How are they going to afford an investment thats ~1/3rd the value of the company? Seems like one of those announcements that no one follows up on to keep them honest?

top_comments.author: cchance
top_comments.text: They wont its another marketing scam by the admin lol, promise shit now, don't deliver reap benefits till the public/admin forgets, you dont actually have to do shit you just have to say you will same as the last time

top_comments.author: ryukoposting
top_comments.text: I find that the easiest way to suss out corporate political advertisements is to look for how they refer to the federal government. If they say "federal government" or "$NAME_OF_ACT" then there's usually at least an inkling of intent behind whatever they say next. If they say "$PRESIDENT administration" or "$PARTY_NAME," you can be certain you're reading a political advertisement.

top_comments.author: chaosbolt
top_comments.text: Yeah, meanwhile >90% of Americans don't want war, yet they will get it... "but akshually it's a republic", yeah, ruled by another country.

top_comments.author: helsinkiandrew
top_comments.text: They also currently have one of the largest debt burdens of their group ($13B - 75% of shareholder equity)
